trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised placebo controlled crossover trial to evaluate the effects of different doses of taurocholic acid in an enema formulation on gastrointestinal hormone secretion and appetite in healthy humans for the future design of treatments for Type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised placebo controlled crossover trial to evaluate the effects of different doses of taurocholic acid in an enema formulation on gastrointestinal hormone secretion and appetite in healthy humans for the future design of treatments for Type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity

conditions.healthcondition: Designing future treatments for type 2 diabetes mellitus

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal oral and gastrointestinal development and function

interventions.interventions: Each healthy volunteers will undergo three treatments (2 with different doses of taurocholic acid 1500mg and 3500mg and one with control), in double-blind, randomised fashion, separated by 3 - 7 days. On each day the test material will be administered as an enema, and each session will last 210 min.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Plasma concentrations of glucagon-like peptide- 1 (GLP-1), Peptide YY (PYY), and oxyntomodulin
primaryOutcome.timepoint: T= -5, 10, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180 min, where the enema is administered at T=0 min

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Appetite scores by visual analogue questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: T= -5, 10, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180 min, where the enema is administered at T=0 min

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Food intake from an ad libitum buffet meal
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Offered over 30 minutes, from 180 - 210 min after the enema is administered

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy subjects; Body mass index (BMI) 19 - 30 kg/m2; Haemoglobin > 135 g/L
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Medications affecting gut function; Alcohol intake >20g daily or cigarette smoking; Significant gastrointestinal disease or surgery; Impaired liver or renal function; Blood donation within 3 months

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study aims to establish whether taurocholic acid, administered as an enema, can stimulate secretion of the gut peptides GLP-1, PYY, and oxyntomodulin, and suppress subsequent appetite and food intake. This information could be useful in designing treatments for type 2 diabetes and obesity.
